title: Ramps support / spacer with 40 mm fan

description.text:
I have designed nothing !
Just combined http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:408305 with http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:408699 and finally added two small "ears" in order to route the bundle properly.
The fan support have a small groove to allow the user to heat the thing and bend it to the desired airflow angle.
To the LCD display users : beware of the lenght of the screen connector which could prevent to install the 40 mm fan !
Let me know about the result ! THX .

Je n' ai rien inventé ! voir liens plus haut.
J' ai juste rajouté 2 oreilles pour le passage des serre cables.
Une rainure sur le support de fan est prévue: on peut chauffer le support et l' incliner suivant l' angle choisi pour que le flux d' air soit bien orienté.

Non-Commerical = No Printing and Selling

title: RepRap Discount Smart Controller to Melzi Adaptor PCB

description.text:
Now available FOR SALE (£10.00 free UK delivery) professional PCB fully assembled and tested.
A fully working RepRap Discount Smart Controller for your Melzi board printer, or any other device that uses this controller board ie engraver, robot, router etc.
Only PCB and on board connectors included.
Use the ribbon cables that come with the display without any modifications.
E-mail or message me for details.
All functions work including the SD card.
If you have a Melzi board on your printer you might want to try this PCB.

I have included a copy of my working Marlin software as an example.
This software example is customised to my Prusa I3 and will need modifying to suit your printer.
Hook up your controller as shown in the picture.
1 on adaptor to 1 on melzi board.
2 on adaptor to 2 on melzi board.

comments.text: I don't live in the UK, and my machine doesn't have the room for this adapter (wanhao duplicator i3). I broke my original screen though, so I hope to use this. comments.text:
Hi Dave,
I've made one of your adapter boards and gone to modify my Marlin source files and hit a snag. The current Marlin development version pin.h file is vastly different to the file you posted here, I think it's now broken up into many pins_XX.h files.
Could you post the original unmodified pins.h source file you used to create yours, and I'll do a file compare to pinpoint your pin changes and see if I can integrate into my current development build. Ultimately your changes might go into the main branch as it's great enhancement to use the regular Reprap Discount Smart Graphics Displays.
Thanks,
Martin
comments.author: Sneezy3D

comments.text:
24 hours later and I've found after reading some of the the Marlin code that the REPRAP DISCOUNT FULL GRAPHIC SMART CONTROLLER is already supported on Melzi boards with no modifications to the pin.h file.
All that's needed on the current version of Marlin is to uncomment the //#define REPRAP_DISCOUNT_FULL_GRAPHIC_SMART_CONTROLLER line and recompile.

description.text:
Hi guys,
This is a Flame Dragon I design by Modio.

The background:
Fear
From the most ancient of Warcraft
Red body
Exudes, burning all the energy
Hot pain, before being destroyed
In Him, you can choose succumb, or evaporation
He is the flame dragon

I really like the Universal connection, so I spend a lot of time try to make something let me feel creative and intelligent.
The result let me feel cool, leg and claw is strong so can stand well, you can easily change the posture so it can "fits within a build volume of 10.0L x 10.0w x 12.5h cm." but you also can stretch the wing to see how majestic it is.
I use three MakerBot Replicator 2 to build three thing files at the same time, raft is must and best to use 0.1mm layer high and 100% infill, all parts is quite small, so better to scale 110%~150% to get best print! Assembly takes me around 40 mins.
Hope you will make it and like it!
Enjoy ;)

description.text: This is a hand held disk shooter.  Pull back the tab on the back and release to fire.  Gravity loaded.

One of the steps we must do is talk to people who have done similar projects. So any advice on how to incorporate a 180 degree pivot? Since a constraint is to have it clamped to the table and from that point we have to hit a random target on a table.

description.text:
This is a pipe plug for square metal profiles. It will be used as a table foot for a homebuilt coffee table. The table is made of welded steel pipes and the foot will protect the floor from the sharp ends.
The pipe cross section is 25x25 mm with a thickness of 2.0 mm

The best animations made by Marvel1901 have been reproduced in pieces of 10x10 cm and composed in a puzzle of 90x180cm
If you print the grid here enclosed and fix it to the wall with glue you can see images moving. The result can be both a big animated wall or single animations. The big panel you see in the video http://youtu.be/QMVlcndasyQ was used to cover the road up of a 3d printing experiment that will start before Christmas 2014 in Turin, at San Salvario district. All about this experiment is secret :) we can say that there will be a lot of 3d printers but we won't sell 3d printers; we will print but we won't print objects on demand ... we will just try to realize something unique... blue... replicable.... After some laboratory experiments a big version has been produced for Paratissima 2014 in collaboration with Eliografia Rossi and Baco3d A 120 cm grid animates 2 walls of 25 m and is moved by 2 vertical plotter https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=E7D3ziQPKX4&list=UUpJyK995z0EB8-_N2hjgHjQ

author: stuveson

description.text: 3 design

caution: The code needs to be updated to use the new library:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:777936

description.header: See instructions for some practical info.
description.text:
A bit about some hidden logic in planetary gears:
Not every combination of tooth numbers allows to distribute the planets equally around the circumference. If the combination allows equal (equiangular) distribution it can be that the planets are a multiple of the minimal mounting distance away from one another (they are not maximally closely packed) making the assembly weaker than it could be.
To allow more tooth number combinations and have the planets as closely/tightly packed as possible the planets can be organised in groups (which is done here). For this the greatest common divisor of the gear teeth numbers defines the number of planet groups (starting points for filling). The number of sun and planet teeth is then defined by multiplicators to that common divisor.
The cycloidical shape of the teeth allows (and requires for small prints) toothnumbers smaller than in involute gears. The compatible tooth number combinations thus become more sparse. Groupling planets by the gcd value and distributing then in patches around the circumference allows more options.
Cycloidical profile pros and cons:
  • smaller toothnumber possible - more compact design possible
  • stronger for same pitch - less fragile teeth than involute profile
    (-) pressure angle can't be adjusted
    (+) it has less parameters than "normal" gears
    (-) pressure angle is varying max-zero-max -> potential vibration -> more wear & friction
    (+) wider contact area (concave on convex) -> less wear & friction
    ? more efficient than involute profile ?
    (-) distance between axles is not continuously variable (irrelevent here)
    (-) harder for subtractive manufacturing
  • smooth profile -> allows higher printing speeds
    v2.0 228 dwnlds
    v2.1 30 dwnlds (explosion view deactivated - timeout problem?)
    v2.2 current (slight shifts for pretty preview removed - due to slicing problems)

If you print splitted parts you need their mirrored versions too.
The grooves on the outside of the ring are for blocking rotation with pieces of filament.
The cylinder where the bearing goes in needs to have matching grooves.
Use jitter if your slicer offers this option.
Printing parts seperately for post assembly makes stringing impossible and may allow for tighter tolerances. But keep the minimum time per layer high enough for the small planets to not deform.
Use nylon if you have such filament at hand.
The 45° bevel cutoffs help preventing fusion of planets with sun and ring when the part is printed assambled and the first layer is squished.
The bevel cutoffs also can aid assembly when the part is printed in seperate pieces.
They look nice too but also weaken the bearings strenght a bit and make it harder to judge the choosen clearance by eye.

title: M10 Hex Nut - 1.5 Pitch - 10mm height - 15 flat to flat diameter

description.text:
M10 Hex Nut - 1.5 Pitch - 10mm height - 15 flat to flat diameter I am making a spool holder using some left over M10 threaded rod, but I have nut M10 hex Fastener nuts. was inspired by the fact that all the other M10 nuts had a 2mm pitch when clearly it has a 1.5 pitch, Fits and threaded wells, not too tight, and not loose
but will try to print at 1.05% larger, but will stick with 1% (original size) when i need to be this tightness it is a short print time, so you can experiment and comment your results. I have had good results with, 30% density
Line Infill
Rectilinear solid infill pattern
(repetier V1.0.4) with my homebuilt I3 rework. 0.4 nozzle
0.40 layer height (quicker but will go with 0.3 or 0.35 next) overnight i can see there has been a few Downloads, if there is any requests for designs, let me know in the comments. comment below if you have had success with this.

M10 Hex Nut - 1.5 Pitch - 10mm height - 15 flat to flat diameter Using the following options:
nut_thread_step = 1.5
nut_diameter = 15
nut_height = 10 I have had good results with, 30% density
Line Infill
Rectilinear solid infill pattern
(repetier V1.0.4) with my homebuilt I3 rework. 0.4 nozzle

If you are like me, you end up with lots of little pieces of filament on your work table. This object allow you to turn a common zip lock bag into a table edge trash bag. Its use is not limited to 3D printing setups, but with all the little scraps you get it is particularly useful. Since it sits under the edge of the table, you don't have to pick up the small pieces of filament, you can just brush them off the table into the bag.  This version improves over the original by adding a spring to the table clamp and thickening some parts so it does not deform over time as much.

You really need to measure your table thickness and use the customizer to get this to work. Put your table thickness in the customizer to get the correct gap size to fit your table. Generate the STL and print out two of them. You don't need much infill since the large parts don't really support any weight.  You probably want to use ABS to get the springiness needed for a good fit on the table edge. If it is out a little to wobbly, decrease the gap a little bit. These print fast with no support needed and don't need much filament so you may want to experiment with the gap to get it to work perfectly. When I printed two I didn't need any cooling.  I'm currently using a sandwich bag. I suspect it will work with other size zip top bags depending on your volume needs. When attaching the zip top bag, fold it over so the zipper gets pushed up into the groove. This will create the needed thickness to keep it from sliding out. Put a holder on each end of the bag and slide it onto your table. You can then scrape your waste right into the bag.

description.text: After hunting for a perfect glass clip and trying a lot of them, I decided to design my own.  The objective was to allow easily cut pieces of glass to be used and still keep as much of the bed available for prints.  These clips are very specifically designed to fit a Printrbot LC with a UBIS hot end, the wooden bed and 6 inch bed heater.  The clearances may not work with other configurations.  The clips will securely hold a piece of 6" x 5.5" single strength glass (1/8 inch) perfectly and allow you to print on most of that space (due to the angled edges of the clips.  It attaches with normal screws which end up sunken in the clip so they don't get in the way of the print head.

Print with high infill (you want these strong) and in ABS (you don't want them to melt).  This is designed to print fine without support.  Note the clips print upside down and you'll need four in total for the bed.

(RF- Russian Federation)

After getting annoyed with spending too much time making a Moxon frame, and not enough time tuning it, I decided to create a frame in openscad. Since the UHF Moxon's dimensions put it outside what a 200mm printer can achieve, I made this one in two parts, which can be interdigitated and held together with fasteners.
There's plenty of room for improvement, but I thought I'd get the design out the door so others can play with it. I deliberately left the mounting paddle fairly featureless because I figured it would be most likely modified by others.
The moxon4.scad file creates one of three parts depending on the value you assign to the PartIndex variable. 1 creates the left panel, 2, creates the right panel, and 3 creates a mounting paddle.

comments.text: Nice design :) Am I assuming right that the moxon just is a wire going all the way around? Would have thought it's more complicated then that^^
comments.author: JulianGoesPro

comments.text: It's a little more complicated. The Moxon is a "partially-folded" two-element yagi. Its chief benefit is a radiation pattern which presents few nulls in the -90 to +90 degree range in azimuth, and the 0 to +90 degree range in elevation. Such a pattern is optimal for an RC setup. See http://w4.vp9kf.com/moxon_design.htm for specifics on design.
comments.author: JulianGoesPro

comments.text: thank you, so basically the feeding part should point to the aircraft and the reflecting part in combination with active element should be levelled horizontally, right? (not sure I have seen guys use it vertically)
comments.author: KerwoodDerby

comments.text: Roughly so, yes. A 2-element Yagi antenna has a director element in front and a reflector element behind. Presumably the Moxon would be mostly oriented about 45 degrees elevated from the ground.
comments.author: JulianGoesPro

comments.text: thanks again :) Will need to build one myself :)
comments.author: KerwoodDerby

comments.text: Among broadly-radiating antenna structures, you don't have to choose, in general. Whether the moxon is oriented mainly horizontal or vertical is secondary to its primary benefit of being a "forward radiator", in the sense that "forward" means "in front of this here RC transmitter".
comments.author: JulianGoesPro

comments.text: so no polarisation... intersting :) Thanks again!
comments.author: KerwoodDerby

Otaku's model is fantastic, but I wanted a version that I could print without all the massive support. I didn't do much, just added a large base (that can be clipped or you can bury it in his pot for added stability) as the original model broke off my platform hours into the print more than once.

I also pulled the arms and added pegs and holes so you can print them separately and then pose young Mr. Groot as he boogies. The pegs are slightly larger than they need to be -- it worked best for me to print and then clip for a nice snug fit into the shoulder sockets.

comments.text: Why such a high temp for PLA?
comments.author: Framingr

comments.text: That's what Makerbot recommended as a print temp for me.  I've seen temps for pla all over the place.  What would you suggest?
comments.author: Framingr

comments.text: Really? Wow the printer I use recommends anywhere between 185-195 depending on the color. I only use temps above 200 when I rarely get some obstruction.
comments.author: AK_Eric

comments.text: Framingr, the temps are different because every brand of plastic is different and even every color within a brand is different as the color is a contaiminate in the plastic so it changes the properties slightly though it isnt always noticeable in all. Also the temp plays a huge roll in bonding, sometimes cooling off to fast or too slow doesnt allow for a good bond so depending on what you need the part to do you need to find the optimal temp for that particular roll of plastic. As for standardizing... i hope things dont change so much that you cannot do similar things across the board but i would hate to standardize an inferior product such as many consumer printers and filament... I like being able to use crappy filament just as much as using the good stuff, they both have their place and there is no monopoly just yet on it!
comments.author: Framingr

title: Netbook Replacement AC Adapter: Power Safety Box

description.text:
A simple box to cover a broken point in the AC adapter in my netbook's cable, which I've resoldered and coated liberally in liquid electrical tape, but still gets bent quite a bit more than I'd like.
This Thing is parametric, and may be tweaked before actually going into use.

Tweak the head variables to suit your own power adapter. All units in mm.
probLen: Length of the problem area in the cable, plus the area you want covered of the adapter.
boxWid: Width of the power box.
boxHig: Height of the power box.

title: [email protected] Redesign of Plastruder MK5

description.text:
Redesign of Makerbot's MK5 Plastruder to fit the standard [email protected] chassis. For more information on [email protected], visit http://fabathome.org/ and http://fabathome.org/wiki/index.php/Main_Page. Parts needed from Makerbot Store: Plastruder MK5 No Relay Board Kit: $170.00 Parts to keep from Makerbot MK5:
â€¢ Filament Drive System: Black Delrin plate and plunger, Large nut and thumb screw
â€¢ Hot end: Everything
â€¢ Drive gear and bearing
â€¢ Small hex nuts (qty: >30)
â€¢ M3 x 22mm socket head cap screw (different lengths, qty: 16)
â€¢ Discard all acrylic plates Additional Hardware needed:
â€¢ #4-40 (2â€) Phillips pan head machine screw (qty: 4)
â€¢ #4-48 (1â€) socket head cap screw (qty: 10)
â€¢ Very small Phillips pan head machine screw (qty: 4) â€“ for attaching motor
â€¢ #6-32 Button head hex socket (1/2") 18-8 stainless steel screw; McMaster #92949A148 (qty: 8)
â€¢ #6-32 Flat Square Nut; Steel; (5/16â€ OD; 7/64â€ thick); McMaster #94855A115 (qty: 4)
â€¢ Medium thermoplastic inserts (qty: 4)
â€¢ Small thermoplastic inserts (qty: 4) Additional parts needed:
â€¢ SM231 Snap motor: https://jeffkerr.securesites.com/snapmotors/orderform.html
â€¢ 3 acrylic middle plates (6-6.2mm thick)
â€¢ 1 acrylic front plate (5.2 mm thick) â€“ for attaching motor
â€¢ 2 acrylic top/bottom plates (5.2 mm thick)
â€¢ 1 acrylic back plate (6-6.2mm thick) â€“ for attaching tool mount
â€¢ Standard [email protected] tool mount (2 acrylic plates)
â€¢ 6mm to 4mm set screw rigid shaft coupling
See file: Plastruder_assembly_instructions.pdf

title: Shapeoko 2 Modular Table Vice V Block

description.text:
Table vice for a Shapeoko 2 that has a 1" grid drilled into it's bed. The mounting points for this clamp is 3" center to center and made for #6-32 screws. They are meant to be used in pairs with an adjustable length of 3/4" on each jaw, which gives you over an inch total (why you have a 1" grid on the bed).
This clamp is intended to be used with either the 1" or 3" clamp (show with 3" clamp)
Companion to 3" clamp: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:468536
and 1" clamp: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:478459

Recommend printing at around 60% infill or higher. After you print them out, adding a strip of foam tape makes a very good grip.
While this is a beefy clamp and does its job well, it still has kind of a funky shape and the sharper edges might want to warp and peel the tape off the print bed, so I 0.45 DIA helper discs. If you have warping issues, try that *.stl instead of the standard one.

update : a revised script and set which includes 4,5 and 6-fold vertices ( slash facets, not sure which to call these ) can be found at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:4934 and http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5028. These two triangular pieces can be assembled into any polyhedron based on equilateral triangles. This includes tetrahedra, octahedra, icosahedra, and many others. The structure of the pieces is such that they resemble both faces and vertices, so the octahedron is also cube-like, and the icosahedron also looks like a dodecahedron. ( a tetrahedron is self-dual, so that doesn't count ).

Print out two each of Y1 and Y2, assemble into tetrahedron
Print out four each of Y1 and Y2, assemble into octahedron
Print out ten each of Y1 and Y2, assemble into icosahedron A range of other shapes are possible. I believe the C60 buckyball is possible with these elements.

title: Quadcopter DJI NAZA M Lite GPS-Mount MT2216

description.text:
This is my first 3D printed Quadcopter and it is exactly customized for the following parts:
-T-Motor MT 2216
-10x4,5 Props (bigger are possible)
-Hacker 4s 5000mAH LiPo
-DJI NAZA M Lite(old version, PMU and LED in one part)
-ESC: every ESC is possible, I use flyduino 20A simonK
-Spektrum Receiver AR9010
The copter with this configuration is really fast and powerful! The copter needs for assembling M3 screws, length: 50mm, 10mm The baseplates also have more holes for attaching extras at the Quadcopter, like a GoPro or Gimbal.

The Indalo is a prehistoric magical symbol found in the cave of "Los Letreros" ("The Signboards") in Sierra de María-Los Vélez Natural Park in Vélez Blanco, Spain. It has been customary to paint the Indalo symbol on the front of houses and businesses to protect them from evil (similar to Kokopelli of the south-western US) and is considered to be a god totem.[1] The indalo has a Levantine origin and dates back to 2500 BC. The pictograph was named in memory of Saint Indaletius, and means Indal eccius (Messenger of the Gods) in the Iberian language.
Sculpture of the man of Indalo in Almería
Legend has it that the Indalo was a ghost that could hold and carry a rainbow in his hands (thus the arch over the head of the man). The Indalo has been adopted as the official symbol in the province of Almería, Spain.[2] The Indalo symbol is used as a lucky charm in the Almeria region also. To carry the charm is only beneficial if it has been presented as a gift. Some people also believe that the story behind the symbol of the Indalo man is about a man who escapes in a cave to get away from the rain, then when the rain stops, out comes a rainbow and when the man walks away from the wall of the cave, the image is left there. The American-based indigenous rights organization Cultural Survival uses an Indalo symbol on its logo.

description.text:
This is a single-print clamp that tightens onto a sheet of thin material in proportion to the tension on a line attached to the other end -- at least in theory. It works well enough to demonstrate the concept, but in this size not reliably enough for the amount of tension I needed. If it were scaled up it might work better. The force required to keep the jaws tight could be that of gravity as well as tension on a line.
The holes in the outer body are intended both to economize on material and to facilitate breaking the inner jaws free after printing.

I printed there without support. There was some stringing and sag, but not enough to impede their functioning.
After printing, press upward on the outer end of the jaws to break them loose from the housing, then pry outward on the spring end of the jaws through one of the side holes in the housing.

description.text:
This case is designed to be laser cut from 3mm acrylic.
The tolerances are very close but the design has been successfully
realised, though even the protective plastic covering upsets the slot
sizes enough to cause issues.
Using 1/8th inch acrylic does not work with this design!
I used 10mm long M3 nylon bolts to hold the board to the base with
nylon washers underneath the board as spacers.
Layer 0 (black) is the through sheet profile cut.
Layer 1 (red) is the connector and slot cutouts
Layer 2 (yellow) is the text
There are a couple of small issues with the design:
  • The SD card slot is very fiddly to access
    This is a working design and has been made by me but I offer no
    guarantee that it will work for you.

description.text: The LittleRP uses a custom one or two axis controller running Marlin but any normal 3D printer controller can be used to drive it. It has mounting holes 60mm apart on the back so I modified an existing holder for a Ardunino Mega board (on which the RAMPS board mounts) to work with the LittleRP. This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/ivvniYA8H9e Update 10/6: The tabs kept snapping off while threading the M5 bolts to mount it. I made them wider, thicker, and made the hole 8.5 mm so the bolts slide (mostly) through. They are anchored in threading on a rail on the other side so they don't need to screw into the tabs.

My daughter, Sophie and I attended this years' MakerFaire in New York.
The Great Fredini scanned her on Saturday and she was very keen to have another go on the Sunday. As she was carrying an umbrella, she decided to have it in the shot. Fredini suggested trying it open and closed to see which would come out best.
As you can see, we now have three marvellous scans that I've put into one model.
Sophie was very pleased with the results and chose the title of this thing.
I did think of making an old style barometer with the sunny/raining rotating figures - maybe another day.
I don't know if anyone is interested in the model itself, but it is worth looking at just to see the quality of the finished scans produced by the Great Fredini and the Coney Island Scan-A-Rama. I highly recommend it if you get the opportunity.
http://thegreatfredini.com/
It's printed 150mm high on a Makerbot Replicator 2 on High settings (0.1 15% 2 shells with support) in ColorFabb BronzeFill. I still need to finish burnishing it...

A bearded axe blade, suitable for mounting on a lego wand or staff and for challenging an extrusion based 3d printer.

Printed with two shells at 0.2mm layer height. The axe blade is a bit thin and narrow for printing, but it can be done. The "adj" file represents tweaking for the print on my replicator2: broadening the axe blade slightly and making the hole a little wider.
The "one piece" file has an integral haft and so prints as one piece, ready to use. Updated to ensure proper one piece file present.
For best results, print at least two axe heads at a time. If you only print one then you'll need to put a wait between each layer to give the plastic a chance to cool.

After watching a ton of videos "how to solder bullets", there are a LOT of bad ones out there. Producing cold solder joints etc...
I wanted something that would hold the wire and the bullet steady while solder was flowed in (the best method of soldering bullets).
Some may say use Helping hands.. but I've always found the jaws leave marks in the wire housing. These do not! They are also plastic to do not conduct any heat away from the soldering process.

UPDATE: I forgot to mention.. Support during the print is required for the arms that cross over both sides (used to hold the wire upright) Here's a video (not mine) that describes the best way to solder bullets:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=n_nr--nwGPo
I do it slightly different, by using a tip on the outside of the cup. As long as the wire is touching the bottom of the cup when you apply heat, it will heat up your tinned wire! You need small diameter solder to fit in between the wire and the cup. I also put a small drop of liquid flux in the cup, not sure if it's required, but it works quite well.
Print 1 of each "Bullet Connector Arm.stl" and "Bullet Connector Column-Helper.stl"
15% infill, 2 shells total
The Helper (part of the column stl) can be used in a twisting motion to open the jaws.
Once printed.. You'll need a piece of Oak or pine it's up to you.. Using a compass draw a half circle.. 98mm (radius) from the center point.. Using a #8 screw fasten the arm on top of the column over the center point used for the compass.
Drill as many male/female holes about 15mm apart on the line you just drew. I believe mine were about 10mm deep (holes are slightly different depth for each male/female)
Male Bullets - #24 drill bit - .144"
Female Bullets - #18 - .169"
After soldering a few bullets you'll need to remove the flux from the hole. The female bullets the hole should be a tight fit, the males can be a bit looser as they have a spring on the tips.
I've always found the metal helping hands leave marks on the wire housings (silicone wire was even worse).  I've tried bending the jaws to reduce the pressure but dents were still left.

UPDATE: I forgot to mention.. Support during the print is required for the arms that cross over both sides (used to hold the wire upright) Print 1 of each stl's (one is mirrored) @ 15% infill, 2 shells total. Screw them to a piece of wood with a #8 wood screw, you decide the distance! Mine are about 50mm apart.
If your soldering mostly smaller gauge wire the jaws could be closer.
Optional. Print helper.stl to help you open the jaws while feeding the wire.

A basic woman made as a test using MakeHuman. http://www.makehuman.org/ I made this in an effort to explore printing the human form on my printer and to learn how to use MakeHuman. The .obj file has the whole body while the .stl files are just torsos. If you look at the .obj file it has jaw bones, teeth, eyes, and extra "joints" (little closed polyhedrons floating inside). I believe I removed all of those extra bits in the "test2.stl" although they did not cause me problems when printing the "test1.stl"
I found it was best to print this upside down (hence the number 2 stl file).  All the pictures are of hollow prints (no infill...)

title: istack ipad and iphone wall mount (parametric)

description.text:
Holds an iPhone in the front and an iPad behind, either can be charged hence the groove in the phone section.
Included the scad file so it can be modified for other phones or tablets.

Yay, My first shared thing..
Originally designed to hold an iPhone 4S and a iPad 3rd gen but I imagine it could be easily modified for any tablet and phone combo.
The current depth between front and rear sections are designed to hold an ipad (third gen) with a smart cover only. 12mm ..
recompile in openscad and change ipad_depth parameter if you have a thicker case.
there are flag variables at the top to generate only the top, only the rear, with or without a slot for the dock connector or to show the parts assembled or next to each other flat for printing.
I printed at 15% infill and 0.3mm layers, it could do with some work to increase the strength of the posts, pulling on the ipad would snap them. I printed hot to get good layer adhesion. If mine breaks I may add some bracing or modify and print a good deal wider to increase the strength.
The two parts are interference fit, I had to sand the pegs a little and clean out the slots in the front parts and then tapped the parts together. Intention was to glue it, but they are not going to fall off.
grab the istack_assembled model if you have a printer capable, print vertically or add support or use istack front and istack rear.
The idea started with the parametric remote control holder, attributed as ancestry.. no code in common any longer though..

title: InMoov Remix of Anar's awesome forearm parts.

description.text:
Remix of Anar's awesome InMoov forearm parts.

  • Forearm_R_RobPart2V2. This version carves back the lip to allow assembly, otherwise you can't slip on the cover.

  • Forearm_R_RobPart4V3. This version has the two missing RobCap mounting holes, and I also smoothed out the bicep pivot.

  • Forearm_R_RobPart5V2. This version has a notch carved out of the lip, no longer interferes with RobServoBed, and Mounting holes have been lowered by 1mm for a better fit with the top cover.

  • Forearm_R_rotaWrist1V2. UPDATED! This version has the wrist servo recess deepened. Also, the servo mount holes have been moved in to match the Servo.

  • Forearm_R_Wristgears3b reduced diameter of horn by 0.15mm to allow mount through rotowrist2 and rotawrist3

  • Forearm_R_rotaWrist2V2 servo head aligned from the mounting hole in rotowrist2
    • 2014-10-25: added wristgears3b, rotaWrist2v2
I'd recommend printing these with at least 3 perimeters, 25% infill.

A basic man made as a test using MakeHuman. makehuman.org/ I made this in an effort to explore printing the human form on my printer and to learn how to use MakeHuman. The .obj file has the whole body while the .stl files are just torsos. If you look at the .obj file it has jaw bones, teeth, eyes, and extra "joints" (little closed polyhedrons floating inside). I believe I removed all of those extra bits in the "test2.stl" although they did not cause me problems when printing the "test1.stl"
I found it was best to print this upside down (hence the number 2 stl file). All the pictures are of hollow prints (no infill...)

comments.text: Awesome! We have a few women printed, but we needed some guys too to be politically correct ;)

author: iPirmin

title: Egg Beater Handles for old style Swift-Whip ball-drive eggbeater

description.text:
Egg Beater Handles for old style Swift-Whip ball drive eggbeater (made in Australia).
Fully parameterised design.
There are two parts: The "Top Handle" and the "Crank Handle knob" The metal of the egg beater will outlast even the "War on Terror", but the wooden and plastic handles break after a century or two. My grandfather used this very one to beat his kids during the great war. These replacement handles are split so they can be retro-fitted to the riveted rods.
File contains a useful function to make spherical section cylinders.

Note that I have two types of SwiftWhip.
The type with wooden handles has different crank dimensions to the one with plastic handles.
Measure yours, and check the dimensions against the SCAD file, before printing them.
These are split so they can be retrofitted to the riveted rods.
A little sanding (eg 200grit) of the inside split line should adjust the part line to be flush.
Before glueing the halves together, clean any bumps out of the inside surfaces, and run for a while to run-in the rod in the hole.
To sand the round rod-hole in the crank handle, put a strip of fine sandpaper over the top-handle rod, and slide the crank handle parts back and forth on it.
Glue together with epoxy or abs solvent glue.
I printed the crank at 0.25mm and Handle at 0.3mm, on Up Mini in ABS
If you want to make them glossy and more waterproof, use the old Acetone trick.

description.text:
RPMify is re-coded from Dave Durant's RPMify for C# (windows only) from:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:4407 This version uses python instead and can be run on any platform The call is "python RPMify.py FILE.gcode MAXRPM"
Where FILE.gcode is the complete path and gcode you want to RPMify and MAXRPM is the maximum RPM you want to run, such as 20. The goal is to process your gcode file one line at a time and replace PWM with RPM
M108 S255 --> M108 R20.0

title: Raspberry Pi Camera Mount for MakerFarm Prusa i3v (OctoPrint)

description.text:
These parts allow you to mount a Raspberry Pi camera with LED illumination on your MakerFarm Prusa i3v to observe the bed of the printer. It's perfect for use with OctoPrint on a Raspberry Pi as a network printer controller.
The bracket mounts to the left bed rail with two M5 screws, washers and T-nuts. My kit had enough extras. You will also need an M3 screw and nut for the finger joint at the top of the mast.
The camera head holds two 1.5W LED corn lights, available from HobbyKing for a couple of dollars:
http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/uh_viewitem.asp?idproduct=26408&aff=624762 In addition to the printed parts, you will also need a piece of carbon fiber arrow shaft. In the US, you can get one at Wal-Mart for less than $4.
A few tips:

First, the Raspberry Pi camera module, Rev. 1.3 cannot focus on the bed from this distance.  To get a clear image from this distance, you will need to unscrew the lens a little.  If you look closely at the module, you can see that the lens is screwed into the front of the camera housing and it's held in place with two or three drops of glue on the threads.  I was able to pick the glue out with a dental pick and then break the lens barrel free with a pair of pliers.  Once it was free, I could easily screw it in and out to change the focus.  I only had to unscrew the lens a little more than one turn.

Second, the holes in the fingers on the camera housing are a little tight for an M3 screw.  A quick pass with a 1/8" drill bit (3mm would also work) cleaned them out nicely.  I also had to sand between the fingers a little (with sandpaper wrapped around a craft stick) to get the joint to fit perfectly.
Third, the colors output by the camera under the cheap HobbyKing LED lights are a little horrifying.  I got...uh...acceptable results using the Horizon and Sun white-balance settings.

comments.text: Nice Design! just printed it and getting ready to install it. Can I ask how you went about wiring the LED lights? and also did you connect those to the pi as well?
comments.author: animado

comments.text: I just wired the LEDs straight to the 12V power supply.  I just slipped the positive and negative wires into the screw terminals with the other wires.  I do have the green wire from the power supply hooked up to the RAMPS so I can turn the power supply on and off with GCODE M80 and M81.  The arduino and the rPi run off the 5VSB line, which stays on when the power supply is switched off.
comments.author: animado

comments.text: thanks for the reply!! I am inspired by the way you improve your printer! I know it might seem like a silly question but it just really sounds interesting the way you turn on and off your power supply with just commands. Is there by any chance a guide or source that you could share about how you went about wiring this? where exactly do you connect the green cable and which one do you replace it with in the ramps, I thought the green cable is only Ground? My idea is to be able to control my printer remotely through octoprint and monitor it with the pi camera.  Thanks again!

description.text:
A Light Shade for LED-tealights up to 40mm diameter and 20mm height (without flame). This Yoda is dedicated to make-up artist Stuart Freeborn who died on February 5th aged 98. He modeled Yoda based on his own face and partly on Albert Einstein.
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stuart_Freeborn If you got too much cash buy a ceramics version there:
http://www.shapeways.com/model/916018
If you are broke download it here and add it to your favorites on Shapeways. :-) (This object is fan art and in no way affiliated with any specific company, product or person)
its about 8cm high and only 1.1 mm thick, so you might want to scale it up for printing and put a normal light into it.

Fresh on the heels of my Marble Tile Gift Feminion #1 wanted to go visit the new Garage. I figured we’d play around for a bit, engrave a Leatherman and be on our way.
Then she spotted the mirror tiles. She said, "there’s no way you could put that in a laser, it’d reflect." I pointed out the laser is infrared, and glass is opaque to it, which is why the lid is clear, and if you look, someone has already etched robots on one of the tiles. "Then we need to etch a big mustache on one so it shows you with a big huge mustache!" Of course we did!
And then we had to make a stand for the tile, but I had already done that Tile Holder. In order words, we needed to step it up. So we made the stand with Mustache footers!
More info at my blog Moustache Mirror

[Seems that thingieverse is interpreting the DXF files as images when I upload them.][Actually Visio exported them and my PDFs to letter size paper which means they were cut off, so I removed them]] Read the blog entry on this for more details. The files have a -2 in their names for the second generation which I did not cut (I make the stand notch taller in the moustache footers).

For the stand we took the previous stand and originally wanted to have 3 moustaches, but we were short on time (we spent 3-4 hours there). We stared at more clip art will we had one which we thought could be modified to hold the tile and stabilize the stand.
We need to cut two notches in the drawing, which had to be fairly precise. Visio is really good at getting precise boxes, so we created two, one for the tile holder and the stand notches. In Visio (moustache-footer.vsdx) , I have a moustache, and two boxes selected:
To reuse the files, you will need to change the size of the tile holder to the width of your tile, and the stand holder to the thickness of your material you are cutting the stand out of. The acrylic we cut for this stand was .2 inches, so I had to adjust the notches compared to the .25 inch material from before. [I just realized I never trimmed the notch on the center piece, that would be a good idea too, you would need to change the Visio object by hand).

The boxes have no lines, white fill and are in front of the moustache.
What we wanted was the outline of the moustache footer, which is tricky. I am not sure how to grab an outline in Visio, so we used the GIMP.
Now merely copying that into GIMP did not work for us at the Garage, but did work now while writing this up.
I rediscovered why copy and paste did not work, it loses scale! I created a -2 version of things with a taller stand notch, but the -2.svg file was the wrong scale (see below).
So copy that into the GIMP (File->Create->Clipboard). Use the fuzzy select too to select the moustache (click any black point).
Next you select all in Visio and export, click on change file type, and save as a PNG (moustache-footer.png). Open that in the GIMP. Click on the fuzzy select tool (magic wand) and select part of the black. Since there is only one object, the whole shape selected.

Now the select is the outline you need. Now save it as a "path": Click Select->To Path

Now open the layers dialog, click on the path tab, right click on the path labeled selected and select export

You need to give it the ‘.svg’ file extension. You can open it in IE to give a quick glance to see if it looks good.
Import the svg into Visio. Now I kept a different doc for the printing because the print defaults in Visio is "print all" and that drives me bonkers, as I forget to click on that frequently, and send all pages to the laser, and then cut the wrong thing.
The easiest way to get it into Visio, is drag and drop from a file explorer window.
Now you can see why I did the export to png, and edit in GIMP. It seems cutting and pasting into GIMP loses the scale somehow. Notice how the 2 version is much larger than 1 or 3. Yet in IE they look the same.

Once here, click on the SVG, and set a line weight of 0.01 (for the Epilog that is how it sees the lines as vectors).
We then printed on cardboard many, many times. We first noticed the notches were not deep enough and then the footers were not long enough as the tile could fall backwards. Now afterwards we discovered that the cardboard was collapsing at the tile holder notch and in the stand notch, so yeah, it was not holding the tile well.

My cousin's rain barrels have clips that hold the hose used to dispense the water.  The problem is that they keep going missing, and she can't find replacements.  So, she sent me one, I made a model of it, printed a bunch, and sent them to her.  Problem solved!

Got the part to be replicated in the mail, measured it with digital calipers, used those measurements to create a model in SketchUp, then 3D-printed the model.  
For you, it should be as easy as printing the part and installing it.

title: Improved Replacement for Reading Lamp Shade

description.text: There are now a wide variety of cheap floor lamps available, some of which have both an upward-pointing main light and a downward-pointing reading light. Unfortunately, the plastic shades can't take the heat trapped in the downward-pointing reading light, and essentially disintegrate. My improved replacement closely copies the shape of the original shade, but with the important difference that it has vent holes to allow the heat to escape, as you can see in the photos. I can't guarantee that this shade will work for you, but I'm pretty sure replacing the original shade with an identical one wouldn't work.

Not much to say. Easily and quickly (for such a large part) prints without supports in the orientation given. It took about $1 worth of white PLA to print it in under an hour on a MakerGear M2.  
The shade attaches using a black plastic screw-in retaining ring, which was intact, so I did not print a replacement for it.

comments.text: The shades are made for CFL and LED  lamps and when an Incandescent is used they just get destroyed from all of that heat.
comments.author: DarkAlchemist

comments.text: That would make sense, but the original shade was marked saying no more than 60W bulb -- not too many 60W CFLs out there, let alone 60W LEDs. It also uses a dimmer switch, which wouldn't work with many of the more advanced lighting options. It probably would have been fine with a 60W pointed up. Incidentally, many of the newer units of similar design now use glass shades....
comments.author: DarkAlchemist

comments.text: Maybe where you are but I have been using 60 watt CFL for decades (75 and 100 watt as well) and just last week picked up 2 60 watt LED bulbs (one was dimmable and one was not) and both were less than 6 dollars in total at WalMart (I was shocked).  The Dimmable one, at Wallyworld was about $3.80 and I am very surprised at how well it looks and works.
comments.author: profhankd

comments.text: Most of what I've seen is "60W equivalent" -- not actually 60W.  Incandescent bulbs put out much more heat than light, so it isn't hard to have a bulb as low as 15 or 20W put out the same light level. Even if it is 60W, the alternative technologies put out less heat (well, except Halogens). Obviously, such bulbs should help shade life... but so should the little holes I added.  ;-)
comments.author: DarkAlchemist

comments.text: That is what I meant as no CFL is going to suck up 60/75/100 watts and why all of those in incandescent bulbs are now illegal, and next year the 40 watt as well, because they really take up that much power.
comments.author: profhankd
